body:
Thanks! Yes. I will fix the conflict that happened after the last commit. And I'll add the shortcuts and do the refactoring for it. Can I ask for a bit of policy on "not importing conf" anymore? I think it will keep out a lot of trouble in the future.

O and something weird I couldn't get my mind around is that I had to set "authenticate" to "false" in the WebUiTests as well despite the tearDown function. If you have an idea on that?
I'll do my best to enforce the policy around conf. I'd suggest renaming it to `_conf` but it may break plugins or external operators / hooks and executors.
@mistercrunch issues have been fixed, all modules have been refactored. I'll have a look at making it _conf apart from this PR as it might indeed break other stuff.
I set up the airflow in the ubuntu ,add the scheduler and then quit from the terminal . it happened to be this .Are there any ways to add the dag into scheduler permanently ?

Did you hit the refresh button on the right side of the red rectangle in your screenshot?

If the link is not clickable it means the scheduler knows about the DAG but the web server hasn't found it yet.
Yes, I click the refresh button,but it still be not useful .  Any solution for this ?
Any way that I can use to add the dag into scheduler and show in the web permanently ? I need it to run every day .
Leave the scheduler running, maybe restart the web server? Make sure they both point to the same `dags_folder`.
OK. I run the scheduler in the remote ubuntu server . it seems this issue happened when I quit the remote ubuntu from terminal .
This is fantastic.
Closing the issue on GH, I've summarized and posted this on the mailing list https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/airbnb_airflow/SAu6gKi_GOo
@Thomasmisfit  Did u solved the issue? I am facing the same problem.

@pedrorjbr https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/123
It may help for you~~

Hello, 

I have a similar experience after upgrading to 1.5.2. I downgraded back to 1.5.1 for the moment to fix the issue. My guess would be it is somehow related to one of the following changes: 
- MySQL uses mysqlclient lib instead of mysql-python
- Using gunicorn instead of tornado as the wsgi web server
@pascalknapen That's awesome. I didn't realise either of those changes happened. Do you have any plans to try out reverting either of those changes?

`mysqlclient` is a fork of `mysql-python` so I would not necessarily expect a huge regression there.
Quick question, are you running a single webserver? (We run several of them behind a load balancer which means that regressions for a single server may be harder for us to detect, and 4 workers (= processes) as per the default configuration). 
Note that the debug server runs on a single thread, and so might be slower as well. Usually one recommends 2N+1 gunicorn workers for N vCPUs. I have a PR out that exposes the ability to use multithreaded workers. Maybe playing with those options might help?

@artwr I just run the server with `airflow webserver`. This preforks 4 workers and one master process. We do use a single server on a single host. It's very slow even with only one person accessing it. It's much faster when accessed directly over an SSH tunnel than when accessed over an AWS load balancer.

@mtustin-handy May I ask why you would use a load balancer if it runs on a single node? It seems that this setup would just increase latency, significantly so if the load balancer ends up being in a different availability zone?
If you have chrome, can you take a look at the developer tools on the Network tab when you load the server URL, and post a screenshot of what you see there?
@artwr Like Amazon itself, we use loadbalancers to make webservers available across network security/availability zones.
@krishnap

I've had a similar problem, that pickles are too big. My response was to add a config option to disable pickling (it previously existed as a flag). Accordingly, if not running locally, all celery workers must have the same code available to them.
If required I can clean up the commits, I seem to have squashed it a bit awkward.

@mistercrunch This seems like it may fix an issue I'm seeing with the scheduler (in that it looks like it's a pretty big change to scheduling). However, I have a question about migrations. How do I use them? I assume there's nothing which applies them automatically for me.

@mtustin-handy @artwr This seems indeed to be related to the interplay between gunicorn and ELB. This article explains it a bit: https://forums.aws.amazon.com/thread.jspa?messageID=419138. As the reply suggests, using async workers might fix the problem. I'll try to find out tomorrow.
Another short term solution might be to bump the number of workers erronously named `threads` in our current config.
`airflow upgradedb`
@mistercrunch :+1: Thank you!
Very nice, I'll merge as soon as you make it pass the travis tests, let me know if you need guidance.
I need this feature too! I would like to kick off a DAG when a file is upload to S3 bucket. Is anyone has a solution for on-event approach?
Sweet, we can add it other places if needed, I can't think of any right now.
No solution yet. Just a thought. With a Notify daemon (to be implemented) that does polling and puts actions into the executor queues when an event happens. lib event (python-libevent) comes to mind
I used a S3 lambda function to trigger an event that starts a docker container in the AWS ECS infrastructure.  So I did not used the Airflow :(

+1

I will develop a workaround using WatchDog. When a dag file is 'modified' | 'created' | 'moved' | 'deleted' i will restart the webserver.
I will close this issue. Related: https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/616

We're not planning on it but I'm sure it would be useful to many in the community. The Airflow team only develops the operators that Airbnb needs. 

You indeed would need to make it seem synchronous if you want other tasks to depend on its execution. If it's hard or impossible to do, you could have a ECS trigger operator that does not execute synchronously and have some other sensor down the chain that waits for an outcome of this ECS job. You'd simply have to make it clear in the operator's documentation that this is just a trigger.

For now the cleanup happens when re-starting the web server.

Short term solution could be to remove from the DagBag on the refresh event for that DAG, which forces people to click that refresh button on the main DAGs view, but I can't think of logical other ways as changing the DagBag's content has to take part in the scope of a web request.

Long term solution is to have a stateless web server serving serialized DAGs (pickles) from the DB
Actually the challenge is that each worker on the webserver has its own DagBag, and that hitting a cleanup endpoint only cleans up one of the workers.

I'm able to do a task "run" without a problem, but if I try to a dag "backfill" it fails with the same pickle error as above.  @wxiang7 I also tried using -sd but that also give the same error.

> if you want airflow being able to execute specific task on a remote box . . .

I'm a bit confused by this, and maybe I am missing something, but isn't this the main point of Celery execution?  Is there some other technique of using celery workers which avoids this?  How does Airbnb kick off jobs on remote workers?

Since PR #540  we support external triggers for DAGs, meaning you can order a DAG run externally, not on a schedule.

The current way to trigger is by using the CLI `airflow trigger_dag dag_id`. I'm planning on adding a `DagRunTrigger` operator that receives a function that if it returns an non-None object creates a DagRun for a specified `dag_id`, the returned object is pickled to the database and made available to the context of all tasks in this DagRun.

Made the changes to support both sync and async workers in gunicorn. Just
finished testing it and working great now behind ELB. Will send a pull
request later today.

> erronously named threads in our current config.

:+1:  For better PR than mine with the extras.

Made the following recommended changes: 
- adding argparse choices for worker_class
- renamed 'threads' to 'workers'
LGTM
Already provided in #618.
:heart:
Closed by #618. Feel free to reopen if needed.

@bryan0 
When you use '-sd' parameter (plus '--local'), you should ensure dag definition files exist on your remote executor disk.

To make "real remote execution" happens, I actually forked the underlying pickler used by airflow (dill), and tweaked airflow a little bit to make remote execution works. But I've no time to merge it upstream for now.

If you're interested in what's going on, you can check the following repos
https://github.com/wxiang7/dill
https://github.com/wxiang7/airflow

Thanks! I am curious. 
In Airbnb how do you execute long running jobs? Are you using hadoop/spark?
Do you have any kind of microservices architecture?
Thanks! I find a similiar post with the answer.

Additionally, the new `DAG.concurrency_reached` also had a problems : 

```
sqlalchemy.exc.InterfaceError: (sqlite3.InterfaceError) Error binding parameter 0 - probably unsupported type. [SQL: u'SELECT count(?) AS count_1 \nFROM task_instance \nWHERE task_instance.dag_id = ? AND task_instance.task_id IN (?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?) AND task_instance.state = ?'] [parameters: (<class 'airflow.models.TaskInstance'>, 'example_bash_operator', 'run_this_last', 'run_after_loop', 'runme_0', 'runme_1', 'runme_2', 'also_run_this', u'running')]
```

Proposed PR here : https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/622

We do execute long running jobs, actually most of our jobs are long running. We do use Hadoop/Hive/Spark/Presto/Druid and more!

I'm not sure what microservice exactly means, but I believe most of our services can't be qualified as being "micro".
![img](https://media.giphy.com/media/98Nrl3nj3FaJG/giphy.gif)
Bump @mistercrunch. Still something funky with IAM roles that I am investigating but this is a great feature for actually handling bigger files.
Looks good! Merge at will.
Closing because merged in #619. Thanks @jlowin!

@mistercrunch you could also serve the dags from hbase or hdfs (or s3, nfs for that matter) which would remove the issue of separate DagBags right?

Or if syncing is required you could use inotify to monitor and send a sync command over rabbitmq to make sure the workers refresh (again I didn't look at the current code)

Well the DagBag is an in memory representation of all the DAGs in the dags_folder. Reprocessing all the DAGs in the folder can't be done as part of a web request, it's just too long. Re-evaluating an individual DAG from a file as part of the web request is not ideal. 

Serializing the DAG to a database or caching engine (memcache or whatever k/v store or the airflow metadata db) has some issues that could be ironed out (serializing a jinja template, non-serializable object put in people's DAG's params or default_args) but may be the best bet. There are still questions as to how who drives the serialization (most likely the scheduler, but what if you don't have a scheduler running?) and how is versioning / cleanup managed... Fun stuff.

Also note that the process of refreshing a DAG in the UI puts a timestamp in the db that is essentially expiring the DAG with a specific timestamp. The DagBag has mechanics to check that timestamp and refresh from source files if its in memory representation is older than the expiration timestamp.
Running on OSX with Python 2.7

Update: This bug is not able to reproduce on v1.6.0

I got the same issue on v1.5.2

Pages:
http://domain:8080/admin/airflow/landing_times (Landing Times)
http://domain:8080/admin/airflow/duration (Task Duration)

I currently need to get our pipeline to hourly. I just switched the DAG to hourly in test and am running into a few issues. For one, `ds` that is passed into my operators is `YYYY-MM-DD` but I need it as an ISO DateTime. How do I get it in 'YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS"? How do you guys support hourly if, when the dag is specified as having an hourly schedule interval, you don't pass the time in ds?
{{ execution_date }} is a python datetime.datetime object, you can format it however you want. {{ execution_date.isoformat() }} or more intricate formating using the `strftime` method
Oh and since 1.6.0 you can set `schedule_interval='@hourly'`
nice!

Thanks for your comments @bolkedebruin 

The mkdir & chmod 777 are indeed workarounds sqlite issues I was getting "unable to open database file", typically related to non existing folders, disk full or user permission, so since I do not have access to Travis to see what's going on, I tried that. Maybe it's superfluous indeed, I'll do a quick commit to test that. 

I think the separate travis envs make sense and could even be improved later by installing and initialising only one DB and its corresponding python lib in the tested environment instead of getting them all as you correctly point out. That would further ensure that a postgres installation really only uses that backend and does not have some undesired mysql or sqlite code going undetected in some dark corner of the code base. 

What do you think?
The problem is actually visible in the Chartkick data show above. Notice the prepended unicode indicator "u" in u'data'.

@adambom and @robbwagoner, this issue should be resolved in the latest version of airflow. Specifying a s3 connection with empty extra will default back to boto's facilities for this. Sorry it took so long.

Feel free to reopen if you still have issues, but I have successfully tested this internally.
LGTM. It makes the testing slightly more complex, but worth it.
Did you fill in the form in `Admin->Connections->Create`?
@mistercrunch See 1.6.0 exception above. I get this when navigating to any DAG. This is a blocker for us.
@r39132 , I think you might need to `airflow upgradedb`. A few models were updated.
The upgrade to 1.6.0 and hourly is not actually working. Airflow is not honoring my DAG specified.
Yes I did, do i need to restart the webserver?

@r39132 Are you sure the database migrations were successful? The migration code to add the "extra" column does exist and should have been executed. Please verify and otherwise maybe add it manually to your postgres db. Furthermore I would check if you are running 1.6 everywhere. and not mixing multiple versions somehow. Clear out the python packages for older versions.

Just reran it :

`$ airflow upgradedb
INFO  [alembic.runtime.migration] Context impl PostgresqlImpl.
INFO  [alembic.runtime.migration] Will assume transactional DDL.`

can you verify which migration scripts are present? can you confirm 502898887f84_adding_extra_to_log is present? Did you install airflow from pip or git?

Did you try to alter the table by hand?

Btw: your host is externally resolvable to a private address, might not what you want to disclose - username is also disclosed.

Hi @bolkedebruin 
I upgraded via git, ran setup.py install, then upgrade db, then restarted my webserver and scheduler. It is possible that the webserver and schedulers were running during the above steps.

It looks like this error is not happening anymore after I killed off a lot of processes and restarted everything.

I confirmed the the migration is present. I have not altered any airflow tables by hand. 

```
./airflow/migrations/versions/502898887f84_adding_extra_to_log.py
./build/lib.linux-x86_64-2.7/airflow/migrations/versions/502898887f84_adding_extra_to_log.py
```

Thanks for the note about the externally resolvable host and username. Rectified, but let me know i there is still something exposed that I missed.

I'm closing this ticket - I have another issue related to hourly start time not being honored, but I will follow up with another ticket.
Closing as I have confirmed that this works on 1.6.0

Does running `pip install airflow[mysql]` help?

The only operators and hooks that are available are the ones you have the required libs installed for.
What is your scheduler's `scheduler_heartbeat_sec` set to? Are you sure the scheduler was running at the time the upstream task ended. Was there other dependencies?
Should be fixed in >=1.6.0 . Reopen this issue if you find that is still the case after upgrading.
Is it stuck on the `xcom_push` call? Database lock?
cc @jlowin
Still a problem? What browser are you using?
Should be fixed in `1.6`
Should be fixed in 1.6 as DAG runs are only created from start_date onwards
So the solution here is for people to ALTER their DB if they want support for larger blobs than SqlAlchemy allocates for when translating.
Dynamic start_date could lead to some problems in the past, I think this should be addressed with cron-like schedule_intervals, dag runs and all the new features in >1.6

Querying the task_instance table for latest run information would definitely need to be done in an async fashion as it may take a moment to load and we don't want to hold up loading the main parts of the page  while waiting for this info.
